content.description: Go through a short overhanging corner to a powerful finish (as mentioned in the guidebook).
content.protection: 5 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: It is the furthest left route on the north-facing side of Gramp's Ramp.

content.description:
Sits on the Sun Tower, as per Tod Anderson's new guidebook. This is located just left of

Lord of the Flies

. It follows a bolt line to a finger crack, then the route moves left past two bolts to an anchor. We thought the crux was going from the last bolt to the anchors. Fun route!
content.protection: 7 bolts to a two bolt anchor. A blue Alien, a #0.5 Camalot, and a #0.75 Camalot come in handy. You can take a run of cams all the way up to two inches.
content.location:
This is located just left of

Lord of the Flies

.  The start could use a weed whacker.

content.description:
P1 (5.12a) delicate technical climbing lead to a mantle and anchors at a comfortable belay ledge.

P2 (5.11c) move right across a moderate slab to another set of anchors, or continue up the arete towards the large roof.  A little sharp, but worth doing.
content.protection:
P1 (8 bolts, 75' to anchors).

P2 (12 bolts & 1-2 1" pieces of gear up high, 75' to anchors).
content.location: This is the leftmost route on Gap Wall, it starts in a thin seam.

content.description:
This shares a start with

Swirly Slab

and needs some gear to protect it. Once on the ledge, follow the bolts on the left.
content.protection: Gear to 3", 3-4 bolts, + a 2 bolt anchor.

content.description: This makes for a great warm-up route.  Pitch 1 is probably not good for beginning trad leaders.  Pitch 2 has too-good-to-be-true holds most of the way to the anchors, with a brief crux at the beginning.  This route can also be a convenient way to access the dead tree ledge by rappel.
content.protection:
P1 (2-3 bolts, gear to 2.5", 100' to 2-bolt anchor).

P2 (11 bolts, 100' to 2-bolt anchor).
content.location:
This shares a first pitch with

Giant Dihedral

.  From the P1 anchors, veer up and right following bolts up a fun slab.  WARNING!!  Use caution when rappelling, as a 60m rope will barely get you down in 2 rappels.

content.description: Very high quality rock keeps you searching for holds.  This route is a must do if you are at the Low Ball Wall.
content.protection: 12 bolts to 2-bolt anchor.
content.location: This is on the Low Ball Wall, below the approach trail.  Look for a well-defined arete with a very smooth left side.  Go right around the small roof at about 55', and stay left of the crack.

content.description: This is a fun route. There is a balancy move about halfway up (watch your feet). Continue to another balance crux above.
content.protection:
8 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor. It can be top-roped by climbing

Giant Dihedral

.
content.location:
Climb the first few feet of

Giant Dihedral

, then climb onto the face and head left.

content.description: Get to the ledge, and climb the face, following the bolts on the right.
content.protection: Gear to 3", 5 bolts, + a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
Start the left of

Sunrise Slab

.

content.description: This is an excellent route. Follow the bolts through a few distinct cruxes.
content.protection: 11 bolts.
content.location:
Begin at the bolts on top of the ledge. Climb the first pitch of

Giant Dihedral

,

Tall Boy

, or

Libertine

to the ledge. From the ledge, this route heads left and up.

content.description: Follow bolts to an obvious, right-trending hand crack.  At the bulge, step left and into a tricky crux corner capped by a roof.
content.protection: 9 bolts and gear to 3".
content.location:
This route is up the center of the Sun Tower, sharing a start with

White Dwarf

and Sun Dog.

content.description: This makes for a good warm-up route, just make sure you use a 70m cord, or double ropes to get down.  It is a classic South Platte slab.
content.protection: 12 bolts to 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: From the base of September Wall, hike southeast along the wall for approximately 100 yards to reach this route.

content.description:
This goes up easy terrain and takes the left bolt line at the roof. It shares the start with

A Day in The Life

.
content.protection: 13 bolts + a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is one route right of

Mr. Kite

.

content.description:
P1 (50 feet, 5.10b). Bring a couple of cams, fingers to thin hands. It is fun stemming in a shallow dihedral, through small roof, to comfortable belay ledge.

P2 (40 feet, 5.8). This is fun, easy climbing. A single 60m rope will get you to the ground from here.

P3 (40 feet, 5.12a/b). This is much harder and thinner but has high quality stone. This requires 2 rappels to descend.
content.protection:
P1. 4 bolts, gear to 2", 2-bolt anchor.

P2. 4 bolts to 2-bolt anchor.

P3. 7 bolts to 2-bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is just to the right of

Lord of the Flies

, or approximately 25' before you reach the end of the gully.  Look for a large flake that looks questionable, leading up into a right-facing dihedral capped by a small roof.

content.description: As named, the difficulties begin right away. Work your way over an improbable early bulge to reach a tenuous slab above and a ledge. From the ledge, trend up and slightly right via some flakes and cracks to reach another challenging crux at the last headwall/bulge.
content.protection: 8 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Begin 20 feet left of tilt in the middle of the face. This has an obvious, intimidating bulge down low.

climbs.name: Shiny Face
climbs.fa: Scott Sills, FFA:  J. Haas, August, 2011

content.description: This route has a very fun start, lots of long pulls off small sidepulls with imaginary feet, and even a dyno to the crying eyes up high.  Good luck.
content.protection: 14 bolts to 2-bolt anchor.
content.location: Start at the leftmost side of the September Wall, sharing the first 30' with Mix-up.  Stem the chimney, pull a small roof on jugs, then step right to the business.

content.description:
This route is just to the right of

Shiny Face

. It starts with 4 bolts, and as you head up, you will use a mix of cams for protection.
content.protection: Four bolts at the start protect the beginning. We used a mix of cams from blue Alien all the way up to #4 Camalot. The 2 bolt anchor is on the left not on the right as per guidebook.
content.location:
It is to the right of

Shiny Face

.

content.description: This route makes a good warm-up on cold mornings, as it's one of the first in the area to see sun.
content.protection: 7 bolts to 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the rightmost route on the Gully Slab, north of the Main Wall.

content.description: After a somewhat crumbly start, stays consistently 10+ on excellent rock with great moves.  Finish on a large ledge where you can access four different second pitch options.
content.protection: 9 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: This is located on the September Wall, just left of a giant dihedral.

content.description: The route is good if you are in the neighborhood climbing the other routes. You move through rock that is fractured and broken up to the first bolt.
content.protection: Four bolts to a 2 bolt anchor. We used a #2 Camalot as the first bolt is a ways off the deck. The climbing isn't hard....
content.location: The route is located at the Line of Sight Wall which is the first wall that you come to as you come down the approach trail. This route lies almost on the the ridgeline.

content.description:
It may look short, but it's an excellent route. The guidebook says 11c, but once dialed in, I thought it was a bit easier. This is incredibly bouldery for the first few moves. Throw a heel, and make a nice static move up.

Beware: there is a death block to the left of the chains.
content.protection: 6 bolts + an anchor.

content.description: This climbs a right-facing corner and then moves to the left wall at a black streak near the top.  The crux is near this black streak.  It is pretty easy climbing until this black streak is reached.
content.protection: Standard rack with an emphasis on small and medium-sized cams.  Two bolts at the top.
content.location:
This route is on the Lowball Wall 2 routes to the left of "

Tilt

".  The right-facing corner is fairly obvious, and it is capped by a roof near its black streak.  There are two bolts for the route "

Minimalist

" about 3/4s of the way up on the wall to the left.

content.description:
P1 - (90 feet, 5.11b) 11 bolts to 2 bolt anchor. Follow overlapping, left-leaning flakes with varied climbing. Must do classic!

P2 - (110 feet, 5.13b) 17 bolts to 2 bolt anchor. Some desperate moves on nearly perfect rock get you into a left-leaning crack, through a hueco, then transitioning into parallel crack/offsets (crux). There is an optional belay here, or if you've got the endurance, continue thru several 5.12 cruxes to the top.
Mr. Kite has varied climbing throughout. There are some runouts over low 5th Class terrain.
content.protection: 7 bolts to chains.
content.location:
It is just right of

Polyethylene Pam

.

content.description:
Scramble up to a right-facing corner with a few bolts. Climb through  this wide slot past the bolts to the roof then into a widening crack. Continue up to a big ledge with anchors.  Skip these anchors and climb the bolted arete to your right to the anchors of

Shiny Face

.
content.protection: Single set of cams to #4 Camalot.
content.location: At this time, this is the furthest left route on September Wall.

content.description:
This route climbs the face to the left of "

Not Alone

".  It starts about 3/4s of the way up "

Not Alone

".  The crux is at the first bolt.  It seemed a bit hard for a 5.9, but the crux is short.
content.protection: 2 bolts and a standard rack.  Two bolt anchor at the top.
content.location:
This route is just to the left of "

Not Alone

".  You climb about 3/4s of "

Not Alone

" and then move onto the left wall and follow 2 bolts up.  Descend from the two bolt anchor on top.

content.description: This is a dark black streak with plants growing out of the first holds.
content.protection: 3 bolts to anchors, or a large crash pad.
content.location: Below the approach trail, south of the September Wall, you will see this bolted boulder problem.  Actually, it would be a sick fall from where the anchors are.

content.description: The route is southeast of Low Ball Wall by approximately 150 yards. Look for 1 bolt at start.  It is approximately 80' to a 2-bolt anchor at top.
content.protection: Bring gear to 3".
content.location: The route is southeast of Low Ball Wall by approximately 150 yards.

content.description: This route has 2 distinct cruxes, with easier climbing at the start and finish.  After you figure out the 1 move trickery about midway, there is a good rest on a ledge before tackling the steep crack above.  Most of the jams are very positive with only one short sketchy section.
content.protection: 8 bolts & gear to 2.5". There are anchors before you enter the upper crack, or continue to another anchor at the top of the crack for full value.
content.location: This is located on the Minion Wall, just left of the Main Wall.  Look for a slab start, leading to a 15' tall offset seam, then into a hands/fists crack.

content.description: A [70m] rope is a must, barely getting you back to the ground.  Fun, varied climbing starting at the right-facing corner, finishing on the steep orange horn.  In the summer, the flies can be bad in this gully.
content.protection:
15 bolts to 2-bolt anchor.

Eds. bring 2 ropes or a 70m rope.
content.location: This is located at the top of the gully, left of the main wall.

content.description: This unusual route has some loose rock at the start, but it is worth the effort.  The top 2/3 is 4 stars.  Try to hit this route early or late in the day, as it faces straight south.
content.protection: 14 bolts to anchors.  Bring a couple long draws to prevent rope drag near the crux bulge.
content.location: When descending the approach slabs, this route is on the left (downhill) side of the wall.  Belay near a small pine tree for afternoon shade.

content.description:
Libertine may seem a bit contrived, but it is a very enjoyable climb. Head straight up the first couple bolts of

Tall Boy

, then go right into the dihedral (all the good holds are there). Then exit right onto the face for a balance crux before nice holds to the anchors. Stay out of the dihedral, and go for 12a.
content.protection:
8 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor. It can be top roped by climbing

Giant Dihedral

.
content.location:
This line is just left of

Giant Dihedral

.

content.description:
This is the left bolted route on the Gully Slab Wall.  You can access the route by a short traverse from the belay ramp used for the other routes here, not a difficult move.

Climb more or less straight up the bolt line, it's decent rock and consistent climbing.  Towards the top you reach a ledge shared by all three routes on this slab - this is probably the crux for many, as you need to climb up onto a slight overhang.  By climbing all the routes on this wall, you could make various attempts on this top portion.
content.protection:
Six bolts (8?) (per Haas, Schneider, Weinhold), we toproped it after climbing

Right of Center

. There is a two bolt anchor at the top, centered on the slab, shared by all three routes here.

Note that the bolts are centered over the crack, so climbing the left or right on TR may result in a swing towards center - it should be a fairly safe swing, but you should warn your beginner climbers.
content.location: This is at the far (left, north) end of the wall.  After finding Radio Head, walk all the way along the wall where you'll likely spot the slab itself, but you'll also see a somewhat dirty gully which takes you up to it.  There is ample space to sit, dump your gear at the top of the gully.

content.description: Slightly meandering at the start, this technical route keeps you guessing all the way to the corner above, where thin fingers are an asset.
content.protection:
8 bolts & gear to 1.5", bring a couple extra finger-size cams.

It is possible to step right to the anchors on

Crandle Hammer Arete

, but the perfect crack above should not be missed.
content.location: This is located on the Minion Wall.  Start on a clean slab left of the arete, finishes on thin fingers corner.

content.description: If this route were twice as long, it would be total classic.  Some bizarre holds facing the wrong directions lead you to a not-so-good jam, continue straight up the bolt line, avoiding the left arete until the very end.
content.protection: 7 (8?) bolts to 2-bolt anchor.
content.location: Look for 7 closely-spaced bolts just left of the Main Wall.

content.description:
Follow the slab up, and take the left bolt line near the top. This shares a start and anchor with

Another Day

.
content.protection: 10 bolts + an anchor.

content.description: As soon as you step from the dihedral onto the face, the business starts.  A short-lived, thin crux leads to really fun edge climbing.  All of a 60m rope is required to lower back to the ledge.
content.protection: 10 bolts, gear to 3.5", 2-bolt anchor.
content.location:
Located just left of

Giant Dihedral

, it shares the first pitch and about 40 feet of its second pitch.

content.description: This obvious route was most likely climbed years ago by an unknown first ascentionist, but Ryan cleaned off a ton of loose rock and added modern anchors, so he deserves credit for that.  If you are doing the route in 1 long pitch, make sure the belayer ties in, as it uses up an entire 60m cord.  It can be rappelled in 2 pitches with a single rope.
content.protection: There are 2 bolts on the slab leading up to the dihedral, the crack takes fingers thru fist sizes.  Anchors at 90' and 190'.
content.location: Start at the base of the obvious, right-facing dihedral.  Rappel down or walk off to the south.

content.description:
Go up and left along ramps and other features to the anchor of

Two Edged Sword

.
content.protection: 7 bolts.
content.location: This is on the Gap Wall and starts on top of the block leaning on the wall.  The two cracks above the block are fun as well, take finger/hand sized gear and end at an anchor about 70 feet up.  They are the first pitches of South Platte Sampler.

content.description: This route is really fun. It is bushy at the beginning. It has multiple starts to get on this route. We used gear through the crux past the third bolt. Like that, you can make this one long pitch. We used a 70 meter. I made two raps to get to the base.
content.protection: 15 draws and gear to 3 inches. I used a #0.5 Camalot, a #3 Camalot and a #2 Camalot. 19 draws total if you run all the pitches together.
content.location:
This route is 2 routes right of

Lord of the Flies

on the Devil's Horn (from Tod Anderson's guide).

content.description: Equilibrium Variation is not too sustained but is a okay warm-up. Clip first 3 bolts, then move on the the easy slab.
content.protection: 7 bolts and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: It is the lowest route on the north face of Gramp's Ramp.

content.description: Approach the dead tree ledge by following 2 bolts through a very difficult slab, or from the right at the base of Line-of-Sight Wall.  From the ledge, ascend an easy slab to a rest just below the bulge. A powerful move through the bulge puts you at the base of a shallow flaring seam.  Thin sequential laybacks with desperate feet lead to a finishing jug and anchors.  A completely unnecessary 5.5 2nd pitch exists, if you really want to get to the top.
content.protection: 9 bolts to anchors.
content.location:
This line is just right of the dead tree on the right side of September Wall, or about 40' right of the

Giant Dihedral

.

content.description: Power through several small bulges on holds of decreasing size to reach the first anchor.  Stop here for a decent 12a, or continue for a much better 12c.  Long, powerful moves thru the large roof lead to a slightly easier finish.  Another Sills classic.
content.protection: 16 bolts to anchors.  There is an optional anchor just below the large bulge if you want to do a 12a pitch without the burlfest above.
content.location: When you first reach the climbing on the approach, you will be descending the slabs right in front of the Line-of-Sight Wall.  Crosshairs tackles the largest overhang on the wall.

content.description: After a thin & sharp start, make one very height-dependent move and continue up the arete.  Tod Anderson's book gives this 5.10d, which I'm sure is correct if you are a little taller than I am.  Shorter people might call this 11+.
content.protection: 9 bolts to 2-bolt anchor.
content.location: This is just left of the Main Wall, on the arete.

content.description:
This is the right and steeper route on the south face of the Corkscrew Pillar. Head straight up a flaring crack system with stems and jams to reach a small bulge and then a rest. From here, work your way straight up through a more challenging bulge using your choice of laybacking or hand jams to make a slightly awkward mantel. Find the sequence through another bulge to meet up with the final two bolts of

Corkscrew

.
content.protection:
9 bolts and anchors shared with

Corkscrew

.
content.location:
It is just right of

Corkscrew

on the Corkscrew Pillar.

content.description: Start at the base of the steeper south side of the pillar. Trend up and left through a few thinker moves to reach a tricky but short slab. Gain a very good flake system that takes you up and right to thin ... as you go to reach a tricky move to gain the final bulge. This is varied throughout. Still, it is a bit dirty but should continue to clean up well.
content.location:
It is the namesake route of the Corkscrew Pillar and is just right of

Corker

about 200 feet to the right of where the approach trail hits the base of the lowball wall and

Sunrise Slab

.

content.description: Start up a mossy buttress to reach lower angle slabs and the base of a steeper by still slabby headwall. Work into a shallow crack system, and then bust left onto a very delicate and thin face. This crux is short-lived but is very foot-dependent and may feel a bit hard for the grade. Once above, this work into a very interesting bulge up high.
content.protection: 10 bolts and anchors.
content.location:
It is located about 200 feet right of the top of the approach trail and

Sunrise Slab

.

content.description:
This is the center route on the Gully Slab Wall.  Once on the ledge below the crack, step up a bit on good footholds to get your hands in the crack.  As you step up more, you can transition completely into the crack, which you can continue until you reach the shared ledge near the top of the route.  There are many face holds and feet, keep off these if you want to practice your crack climbing.

Towards the top, you reach a ledge shared by all three routes on this slab - this is probably the crux for many, as you need to climb up onto a slight overhang. By climbing all the routes on this wall, you could make various attempts on this top portion.

It is not a bad route if you want to introduce someone to crack climbing - they can switch to face holds if they get tired and it's low angle, so not as painful as complete vertical.
content.protection: Most simple would be an assortment of finger and hand-size pieces.
content.location: This is at the far (left, north) end of the wall. After finding Radio Head, walk all the way along the wall where you'll likely spot the slab itself, but you'll also see a somewhat dirty gully which takes you up to it. There is ample space to sit, dump your gear at the top of the gully.

content.description:
To the right of

Sun King

/

A Day in the Life

, climb the slab to an anchor below the roof.
content.protection: 7 bolts + an anchor.

content.description: Muscle through a tricky bulge, pull on tiny edges with imaginary feet to a small roof, then smear & mantle to an easier finish.
content.protection: 9 bolts to 3-bolt anchor.
content.location:
30' right of the

Giant Dihedral

, beginning on the left side of the dead tree ledge.  Approach the ledge from the right, at the base of Line-of-Sight Wall, or grunt through a difficult 2-bolt direct approach from below.

content.description:
This climbs a big, right-facing dihedral.  There is some lichen at the bottom, but with care, it can be avoided.  The crux is about 3/4s of the way up, but the protection is good.  You can clip the last bolt on

"Tilt"

if you want.  I did this as I had already used my biggest cams lower in the dihedral.
content.protection: Bring a standard rack.  One book says to bring gear to 3", but a bigger piece like a #4 Camalot will protect the beginning.  There are two bolts fixed for descent at the top.
content.location:
This route is on the Lowball wall right of the route known as

"Tilt"

.  It ascends a big, right-facing dihedral.

content.description:
This is burly on both pitches, involving about every crack climbing technique.

P1 (100', 14 bolts to 2-bolt anchor, 5.11b).

Start at a bolted, flared chimney.  Scott originally climbed this clean with gear, but this would have warranted an R/X rating with the scarcity of good protection available.  After the chimney pinches down, the route veers to the left on thin crimps, then up to a comfortable belay just below the large bulge.

P2 (100', 2 bolts & gear to 4" to anchor, 5.10d).

Follow the hand to fist crack through the bulge.  If you are uncomfortable with this grade, bring one #4 Camalot in addition to the standard rack.  This route was most likely aid climbed by an unknown party before being discovered and cleaned by Scott Sills in 2003.  Old gear was found hanging in the crack.
content.protection: Standard rack through 4".  Good anchors at comfortable belays.
content.location: This is the center route on the Main Wall, with pitch 2 ascending the beautiful splitter crack through the bulge.

content.description: Some nice face climbing leads to a short, overhanging corner. Continue up the face to a finishing hold.
content.location: It is on the North-facing side of Gramp's Ramp in the middle of the face.

content.description:
Begin with a shared start with

Glass Onion

, then take the rightmost bolt line when it splits near the top. It also shares an anchor with

Glass Onion

.
content.protection: 8 bolts + an anchor.

content.description: This route is ok if you happen to be passing by it, but I wouldn't recommend it as a destination.
content.protection: 5? bolts to 2-bolt anchor.
content.location: When approaching the crags, there is an easy walk down off the ridge about halfway from the parking area to the descent slabs.  There is a short wall with one route on it, going through a big hole about 15' up.

content.description:
This shares a start with

Sun King

but takes the right bolt line near the roof. Bring a 70m rope.
content.protection: 13 bolts + an anchor.
